;香港陷入困境的国泰航空需要大量重建工作来修复其破败不堪的局面形象，但也必须让员工做得更好，让他们感到自豪，公司大使不仅仅是员工，品牌和公共关系专家说。

;

;由于该市的旗舰航空公司卷入了涉及三人的歧视丑闻，因为 -解雇了空乘人员，专家们表示，虽然这三人树立了一个坏榜样，但并非所有员工都是这样，如果存在这种倾向，管理层也必须反思其角色，而不仅仅是暗示它与适当的培训有关。

;

;他们说，这与应该渗透到整个组织的企业文化有关，每个人都意识到他们所代表的品牌。

;

;飞行风险：解决香港国泰航空飞行员的不满

; h3>;

;周日，在成都飞往香港的航班上，一名说普通话的乘客指责三名空乘人员嘲笑乘客的英语能力，这让国泰航空陷入了丑闻。

;

;该乘客发布了自己的声音周一，内地社交媒体平台小红书上有一段空姐对话的录音，其中一位说：“如果你不能说‘毯子’，你就不能拥有它。”

;

;国泰航空的社交媒体账号已被评论泛滥，主要来自愤怒的大陆用户，贬低其服务标准。

;

;在事件报告出现后不到 48 小时，首席执行官林兆波周二晚间宣布，三名船员已被解雇后，他发誓要成立一个跨部门的工作组，以改善公司“客户至上”的文化。

;

;周三，他还用普通话向受影响的乘客和公众道歉，这是该公司第四次表达三天后后悔。

;

;行政长官李家超也表达了对事件的愤怒和失望，要求得到答复，并称这损害了香港的声誉。

;

;在一份内部文件中Lam 在周四发给所有员工的备忘录中表示，该事件反映了“我们需要解决的更深层次的问题”，该航空公司“必须谦虚反思，深刻审视我们的文化并采取具体措施”来扭转其形象。;

;研究危机管理的中国大学新闻与传播学院副教授 Kaman Lee 周五表示，丑闻表明不止一个问题困扰着公司。

;

;“这不是公共关系问题。这是一个企业问题，”李说，并指出国泰航空的形象和声誉近年来已经恶化。

;

;香港的国泰航空歧视丑闻：为什么机组人员表现如此糟糕？

;

;相反除了只关注前线员工是否接受过培训，Lee 表示，公司应该调查员工无法提供专业服务的原因。

;

;“为什么会发生这样的不专业事件？是不是涉及很多因素？”她说。 “这是招聘问题……还是为什么我们不能很好地培训员工？”

;

;Lee 补充说：“管理层需要让员工感到他们受到尊重，并且有支持他们的渠道。我们是否需要在薪资和福利方面改善员工待遇……以及如何让员工无忧无虑地工作。”

;

;她指出，这些都是有助于提高员工绩效的因素。

;< p>;“如果一家公司未能让员工心甘情愿地成为[公司]大使，那么这一定表明存在一些问题，”她说。

;

;为了提升其公众形象，国泰航空也应该她说，就跟进程序的效率和透明度而言，在处理危机和投诉方面始终如一。

;

;当地广告公司饿了么数码的董事 Rudi Leung Chi-sing 说，这次失败表明它确实做到了如果不对员工付出多少努力，无论航空公司在广告上投入多少。

;

;梁说，国泰的回应可能“过于抱歉”，这可能会“严重影响”内部士气。< /p>;

;“我们所知道的只是录音中发生的事情，我们不知道中间发生了什么，例如与客户的互动以及所涉及的情绪，”他说。

;

;“在处理这件事时，国泰就干脆下跪，可见没有考虑到员工的士气。”

;

;梁振英说，国泰不可能阻止这股洪流。互联网投诉，公司应该保持冷静，直接与相关客户打交道。

;

;“中国是一个大国，你无法应对所有的舆论，”他说。 “人若不服，多道歉三句也没用。可以没完没了。”

;

;国泰将加紧挽救声誉，将“虚心反思”丑闻

;

;他补充称，为挽救声誉，国泰只能“走Leung 说，通过向来自不同国家的乘客展示其空乘人员对乘客的尊重来“谈话”。

;

;从管理的角度来看，高管们应该始终在立即指责之前了解情况。

;

;中国大学航空政策与研究中心的袁志乐表示，国泰航空的反应在损害控制方面“迅速有效”，但从长远来看，有些问题必须妥善解决。

;

;“首先，国泰航空需要在中国大陆重塑形象，重新赢得当地客户的信任。其次，除了审查其服务协议和培训流程外，更重要的是要加强其以客户为中心的企业文化，”他说。

;

;“第三，领导层提高员工素质也很重要”

;

;Yuen 表示，由于劳动力短缺，疫情过后全球航空业的服务质量出现下降。

;

;“鉴于形势严峻，为员工建立一个协作和相互尊重的工作场所变得至关重要，”他说。

;

;香港平等监管机构警告国泰员工可能违反了歧视法

;

;与此同时，在国泰航空服务了八年的安迪*表示，他和他的同事认为国泰航空对事件的处理过于“突然”和“极端”。

;

;“即使这只是一种行为，[管理层] 可以花更多时间进行调查，这样人们就会知道他们确实试图了解情况和相关人员，”他说。

;

;“一切都发生得太快了。这给人一种感觉，他们正试图给空乘人员一个例子，并迅速结束丑闻。”

;

;他说，自丑闻发生以来，他的同事们的士气变得低落，其中一些人甚至“害怕”去上班。

;

;“他们害怕自己会说错话并被记录下来，然后突然被解雇，”他说。 “感觉就像我们没有受到保护，很容易被解雇和替换。”

;

;他补充说，同事之间甚至谈话都感到不安，因为担心有人可以记录谈话，并表示担心这种情况可能引发

;

;安迪说，并不是所有的空乘人员都需要会说普通话，因为有些不是中国人，但他相信航空公司将来可能会提供可选的语言培训。

;

;他说，在为看起来像亚洲人的乘客提供服务时，国泰空乘人员通常会先说英语，然后再使用其他语言并观察他们的反应。

;

;“如果我和日本乘客说普通话，也可能算作歧视，”他说。

;

;但 Andy 指出，这还取决于空乘人员在说不同语言时的个人经验，因为有些人在服务多年后可能能够区分来自不同国家的乘客.

;

;香港国泰航空试图化解侮辱丑闻，工会抨击管理层

;

;国泰航空机组人员工会周三对这一事件表示遗憾，但表示士气处于历史最低点，尽管工作量增加，薪酬减少，但航空公司仍面临人力短缺。

;

;工会还敦促公司解决问题的根源，重建合理和安全的工作环境，以提高员工士气。

;

; p>;

;但这家航空公司周四发表声明称，该公司不会宽恕、支持或同意工会在此事上的立场。

;

;*应受访者要求更改姓名。

; Sat, 27 May 2023 08:50:02 +0800 How Hong Kong can give the world reasons to fall back in love with ithttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3221721/how-hong-kong-can-give-world-reasons-fall-back-love-it?utm_source=rss_feed

;香港正处于十字路口。这座城市需要彻底重新思考其在全球范围内的角色，并了解如何重塑其品牌及其认知方式。多年来，香港作为居住、职业或度假胜地的声誉不断恶化。我们必须改变这种状况，以便更好地具有国际竞争力。

;

;我们在 1,100 平方公里的范围内拥有世界一流的基础设施、美丽的海滩、美丽的山脉和闪闪发光的摩天大楼。尽管许多主要城市都在为结构性问题苦苦挣扎，高税收和犯罪率居首位，但香港仍然是一个安全、交通便利、充满活力和充满活力的生活、工作和旅游之地。

;

;那么如何我们改变叙事，呈现新香港？我相信答案是专注于成为一个国际生活方式中心，同时发挥我们作为全球金融中心的作用。如果香港要成功吸引新人才、打造家族办公室中心并保持国际竞争力，就需要提供世界所需的生活方式。

;

;在大流行前，2018 年香港创下了纪录6500万游客，其中5100万来自中国大陆。现在，在大流行后的世界中，我们应该更加雄心勃勃。我们需要保持和增加大陆游客的数量，但我们也必须找到令人信服的理由来吸引地区和国际游客。我们成功的关键在于更全面和更具战略性地思考。

;

;考虑娱乐。周杰伦本月在中环海滨举行的系列演唱会票房一空，不仅吸引了香港和内地的歌迷，还吸引了新加坡、马来西亚和印度尼西亚的歌迷。香港需要成为全球艺术家亚洲巡演的必经之地。同时，我们必须与主要的商业和文化活动协调，以吸引合适的游客群体并创造双赢的吸引力。

;

;体育也必须是关键。香港七人榄球赛是我们向世界宣布这座城市在大流行病后恢复营业的一部分。我们将在 2024 年启用可容纳 50,000 人的新启德体育馆。我们现在应该与足球国家进行战略合作，以吸引世界一流的球队参加邀请赛。想象一下，如果曼彻斯特城队与国际米兰队在香港举行欧冠复赛，我们会在地区内引起多大的兴趣？

;

;作为国际赛事的一部分，我们正重新投入到举办世界级高尔夫和网球赛事的浪潮中。电路。具体来看高尔夫，我们的政府最不应该做的就是侵蚀这些生活方式资产。我们将失去培养本地人才和赶走国际游客的机会。

;

;除了娱乐和体育，艺术和文化也是国际生活方式中心的关键要素。 M+视觉文化博物馆和故宫博物院是我们的新宝藏。我们如何进一步利用它们？我们已经举办了非常成功的巴塞尔艺术展、香港国际电影节和众多贸易展览会。

;

;香港现在需要与我们的国际同行进一步推广和创造定期、受欢迎的活动。想想法国五月节、慕尼黑啤酒节和泰国泼水节等活动，将香港打造成真正的亚洲国际都会。

;

;在我们与国际合作伙伴合作的过程中，美酒佳肴外交也必须高度重视我们的国际生活方式中心议程。由于我们的零税环境，香港已成为葡萄酒中心。政府现在应该发挥想象力，考虑让香港成为威士忌中心并取消税收，特别是稀有威士忌拍卖。

;

;那么下一步该何去何从？我看到三个优先事项。首先，政府和企业必须齐心协力，设计可持续的长期计划，以实现国际生活方式中心的目标。其次，我们需要创建一个团队并提供资源，专门执行由新任命的全球香港品牌大使领导的计划。

;

;国泰、李锦记等超级品牌是香港的超级大国< /h3>;

;第三，我们必须更好地改变观念，让香港重新成为世界地图上的生活方式和体验目的地，同时消除所有持续存在的错误和损害声誉的包袱。

;

;香港有潜力重新获得其作为标志性全球目的地的地位。我们只需要给人们理由重新爱上我们。

;

;美国当局逮捕了两名涉嫌参与北京阴谋的中国政府特工以扰乱并最终推翻流亡的反共法轮功精神运动。

;

;周五启封的起诉书指控陈约翰和林峰策划撤销总部设在纽约的法轮功组织的免税政策身份并向一名冒充美国税务代理人的卧底官员行贿。

;

;卧底官员记录了与陈的多次谈话，调查人员获得了窃听电话记录了陈和冯讨论他们据称接受的指示的电话”奖励卧底官员帮助打击法轮功的非营利地位。

;

;70 岁的美国公民陈和 43 岁的合法永久居民冯被控作为外国政府的未注册代理人，贿赂公职人员并串谋进行国际洗钱。

;

;陈和冯都出生在中国，但现在住在洛杉矶地区，他们于星期五。无法立即获得有关首次出庭或可以代表他们发言的律师的信息。

;

;寻求评论的消息已发给中国驻华盛顿大使馆和法轮功运动。

;

;中国于 1999 年取缔法轮功运动，将其列为邪教和“五毒”之一，或对其统治的主要威胁。从那以后，法轮功修炼者在纽约州北部一个名为 Dragon Springs 的 400 英亩大院内找到了避难所。

;

;针对法轮功的中国邪教破坏者面临腐败调查

;

;在美国, 法轮功运动主要以其与巡回表演艺术团体神韵和大纪元的联系而闻名.

;

;司法部近年来进行了一系列起诉，以破坏中国在美国识别、定位和压制亲民主活动人士和其他公开批评北京政策的人的努力。外国政府的这种做法被称为“跨国镇压”。

;

;“中国政府再次试图针对在美国这里批评[中华人民共和国]的人，但没有成功，”总检察长梅里克·B·加兰 (Merrick B. Garland) 在一份声明中说。

;

;加兰补充说，美国将“继续调查、破坏和起诉”中国“压制其批评者并将其政权的影响范围扩大到美国本土”。

;

;联邦检察官称，为了破坏法轮功，陈和冯敦促美国国税局撤销该组织的非营利性税收地位。在 2 月份向税务机构的举报投诉中，陈将法轮功描述为“巨大的超级邪教”——呼应了中国政府用来描述该运动的语言。

;

;然后陈和冯转向卧底检察官说，如果税务机构进行审计，官员会确保 IRS 对投诉采取行动，悬赏 50,000 美元，并交出 5,000 美元现金作为首付款。

;

;陈会见了检察官说，5 月 14 日在纽约北部的一家餐馆。检察官说，几天后，这名官员用伪造的美国国税局信笺给陈写了一封信，称该机构已对法轮功立案。

;

;陈通过窃听电话将消息转达给冯，检察官表示，这表明他正计划向中国政府官员通报最新进展。

;

;美国逮捕了 2 名涉嫌在纽约经营中国“秘密警察局”的嫌疑人

;

;陈和冯被捕一个月前，司法部指控两名男子代表中国政府在纽约建立秘密警察局。

;

;大约在同一时间，联邦检察官指控中国国家警察部队的大约三打官员使用社交媒体骚扰美国境内的持不同政见者。

;

;2020 年，司法部指控六人代表中国政府在旨在胁迫新泽西州的压力运动中工作北京通缉男子返回中国接受指控。

; Sat, 27 May 2023 07:50:02 +0800 Killer whales damage boats in Spanish, Portuguese waters in puzzling new behaviourhttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/3222011/killer-whales-damage-boats-spanish-portuguese-waters-puzzling-new-behaviour?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;本周，一群虎鲸在直布罗陀海峡反复撞击一艘游艇，它的损坏程度足以让西班牙救援人员前来帮助其四名船员。

;

;这是伊比利亚半岛大西洋沿岸虎鲸行为令人困惑的趋势的最新一集，它已经离开研究人员正在寻找原因。

;

;西班牙海上救援服务部门表示，星期三晚些时候，虎鲸多次撞上悬挂英国国旗的 20 米（65 英尺）长的船只 Mustique，导致其船舵失灵不起作用并开裂它的船体。西班牙救援人员需要先抽出海水，然后再将她拖到安全地带。

;

;西班牙救援部门表示，警报通过英国救援人员转达了求救信号。一架直升机和一艘救助艇被部署来帮助受损的船只停靠在巴尔巴特。

;

;这是该服务今年记录的第 24 起此类事件。该服务没有提供去年的数据。

;

;但大西洋逆戟鲸工作组是一个由西班牙和葡萄牙海洋生物研究人员组成的团队，负责研究伊比利亚半岛附近的虎鲸，他们表示，这些事件首先报告于三个几年前。 2020 年，该小组记录了 52 起此类事件，其中一些导致方向舵损坏。到 2021 年，这一数字增加到 197 条，到 2022 年增加到 207 条。

;

;虎鲸似乎瞄准了覆盖伊比利亚半岛西海岸的宽阔弧形范围内的船只，从直布罗陀海峡附近的水域到西班牙的加利西亚西北部。

;

; Sat, 27 May 2023 06:20:01 +0800 Winnie the Pooh is teaching Texas kids how to survive school shootings – and parents are upsethttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3222009/winnie-pooh-teaching-texas-kids-how-survive-school-shootings-and-parents-are-upset?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.27 06:02;
;;

;Cindy Campos' five-year-old son was so excited about the Winnie the Pooh book he got at school that he asked her to read it with him as soon as he got home. But her heart sank when she realised it was a tutorial about what to do when “danger is near”, advising children to lock the doors, turn off the lights and quietly hide.

;

;As they read the Stay Safe book the school sent home without explanation or a warning to parents, she began crying, leaving her son confused.

;

;“It's hard because you're reading them a bedtime story and basically now you have to explain in this cute way what the book is about, when it's not exactly cute,” Campos said.

;

;She said her first-grader, who goes to the same junior school as her pre-K son, also got a copy of the book last week. After posting about it in an online neighbourhood group, she found other concerned parents whose children had also brought the book home.

;

;The district's decision to send children home with the book has made waves. California's Democratic governor, Gavin Newsom, tweeted: “Winnie the Pooh is now teaching Texas kids about active shooters because the elected officials do not have the courage to keep our kids safe and pass common sense gun safety laws.”

;

;It sparked enough of a reaction to warrant an explanation from the Dallas Independent School District, which said in a statement on Friday that it works “hard every day to prevent school shootings” by dealing with online threats and improving security measures. It also conducts active shooter drills.

;

;“Recently a booklet was sent home so parents could discuss with their children how to stay safe in such cases,” the district said. “Unfortunately, we did not provide parents any guide or context. We apologise for the confusion and are thankful to parents who reached out to assist us in being better partners.”

;

;The district did not say how many schools and grades in the district received the books.

;

;Frequent shootings put US mass killings on a record pace

;

;Campos said the book was “haunting” her and that it seemed especially “tone deaf” to send it home with children without explanation around the time the state was marking the anniversary of last year's mass shooting at an junior school in Uvalde, when a gunman killed 19 children and two teachers.

;

;It also comes as Texas' Republican-controlled legislature wraps up a session in which it rejected virtually all proposals to tighten gun laws but did pass legislation banning school libraries from having books that contain descriptions, illustrations or audio depicting sexual conduct not relevant to the required school curriculum.

;

;Active shooter drills have become common in American schools, though there is disagreement over whether they do more harm than good.

;

;Campos said that although she does not disagree with the book's intent, she wished it would have come with a warning to parents so that she could introduce it to her children at the right time and in the right way. She said she has discussed school shootings with her children, and that she might have chosen to wait to read them the book until there was another attack.

;

;“I would have done it on my own time,” said Campos, who first spoke to the Oak Cliff Advocate.

;

;The book's cover says: “If there is danger, let Winnie the Pooh and his crew show you what to do.” Inside, it includes passages such as “If danger is near, do not fear. Hide like Pooh does until the police appear. Doors should be locked and the passage blocked. Turn off the light to stay out of sight.”

;

;The book was published by Praetorian Consulting, a Houston-based firm that provides safety, security and crisis management training and services. The company, which did not respond to messages seeking comment, says on its website that it uses age-appropriate material to teach the concepts of “run, hide, fight” – the approach authorities say civilians should take in active shooter situations.

;

;The company also says on its website that its K-6 curriculum features the characters of Winnie the Pooh, which are now in the public domain and even featured in a recent horror film.

; Sat, 27 May 2023 06:20:01 +0800 Why India will continue to lag behind China as a global economic powerhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3221803/why-india-will-continue-lag-behind-china-global-economic-power?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.27 06:15;
;;

;Over a 40-year career trying to understand the dynamics behind the extraordinary emergence of Asia's economies, perhaps only one question has attracted more debate than whether or when mainland China will attack Taiwan: why has India always lagged behind China, and is that about to change?

;

;The issue has erupted afresh in part because the United Nations says India last month overtook China as the world's most populous nation. It has also been driven by India's strong recent economic growth, and Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to project India as a leader of the Global South. India's chairmanship of the Group of 20 this year, and its hosting of the G20 summit in New Delhi in September, has also prompted chatter about India's rise.

;

;But a further factor has been America's remorseless efforts to slow China's rise, and to reduce the ever-widening range of Chinese goods on which US manufacturers and consumers have come to rely. Every attempt to devise a credible decoupling, diversification or derisking strategy points Joe Biden's team inevitably to India – the only economy with a big enough market and workforce to develop the economies of scale needed to have a hope of competing against China.

;

;But India, for more than 40 years, has remained a miracle about to happen. Back in the 1980s, along with thousands of other Western companies, my then-employer the Financial Times was wrestling with how best to focus its Asian expansion plans: prioritise Hong Kong, focused on the China market, or in Mumbai, focused on India?

;

;For FT bosses, the answer was obvious: India was the world's largest English-speaking market, the world's most populous democracy, and home to one of the world's largest equity markets. It also had long-standing links with Britain.

;

;Arguments that China's leadership was far more pragmatic and seriously committed to opening up to international trade and investment, with the foundations of an urban-industrial psychology that contrasted with India's profoundly rural-agrarian mindset, were brushed aside. To the best of my knowledge, the FT is still battling to publish in India.

;

;My deep doubt that India can become a top-table power that might serve as a democratic counterweight to China was forged in the 1970s by social scientist Barrington Moore's Social Origins of Dictatorship and Democracy.

;

;In asking why India failed to succumb to a Marxist revolution after independence in 1947, while China emerged under Mao Zedong as a radically transformed Marxist power, Moore identified a wide range of powerful inertial forces in India that prevented revolution and shackled economic change – and continue to do so even today.

;

;Perhaps most important were the rural power structures cemented around caste, which still exert more influence over social and economic development than most economists recognise.

;

;In China, revolution swept away ancient power structures, entrenched corrupt networks and ossified vested interests. Corrupt networks could regrow but the inertial undergrowth that had for a century choked change in China had been cleared, opening the country to a potential for change.

;

;The absence of revolution in India left in place existing power structures and long-standing vested interests, along with the corruption they nurtured, blocking the radical political or economic changes that turbocharged China's economic growth from the late 1970s. Corruption remains a scourge in India and a nagging obstacle to growth.

;

;There is magical thinking among forecasters who talk of an “Indian century”, with Modi's India set to overtake China, not simply in population but as a dynamo for global growth.

;

;Alok Sheel, a former secretary of India's Economic Advisory Council, injected some much-needed realism: “If India were to grow at the very optimistic, and currently unlikely, rate of 9 per cent going forward, and China were to slow down to 4 per cent, the Indian economy would be 70 per cent of China's size by mid-century.”

;

;So many factors sit in the way of sustainable strong growth in India. Nearly 43 per cent of the population works in the farming sector, compared to 25 per cent in China. Underemployment, much of it informal and undocumented, hampers any pathway to higher productivity.

;

;India is far from ready to take China's place in the global economy

;

;While India's education spending is higher than in China (as a percentage of government expenditure), literacy remains at 74 per cent, compared with 97 per cent in China, with almost 27 per cent of India's population lacking any formal education. Women account for a large share of the illiterate, contributing to the reality that just 19 per cent of women participate in the workforce, compared with 61 per cent in China.

;

;A failure to spend adequately on education, health, social welfare and other key infrastructure also shackles progress. Just 46 per cent of Indians have access to safe sanitation (compared with 70 per cent in China), and only 43 per cent have access to the internet (70 per cent in China).

;

;One can juggle data ad nauseam, but the reality of the past 40 years remains unchanged: Indian progress is welcome but slow, and the country will continue to lag behind China.

;

;The rising economic heft of the Global South will give India a seat at top tables like the G20, but there is no way Biden can magically think away the reality of China as a global economic force. The 21st century may not be India's century, but it is almost certainly Asia's century, and Washington needs to come to terms with that.

; Sat, 27 May 2023 06:20:01 +0800 US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen pushes back debt ceiling deadline to June 5https://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3222008/us-treasury-secretary-janet-yellen-pushes-back-debt-ceiling-deadline-june-5?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.27 05:30;
;;

;Democrats and Republicans inched towards a deal on Friday to avoid a crippling US debt default – and won a bit of extra breathing room as the Treasury Department pushed back the date the government's money will run out.

;

;Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the dreaded X-date will now be June 5, not June 1, if Congress fails to lift the debt ceiling, authorising increased government borrowing.

;

;Yellen, however, warned that the deadline extension does not change the urgency to end the stand-off in Congress.

;

;“Waiting until the last minute to suspend or increase the debt limit can cause serious harm to business and consumer confidence, raise short-term borrowing costs for taxpayers, and negatively impact the credit rating of the United States,” she said in a letter to top Republican Kevin McCarthy.

;

;There were glimmers of optimism. According to unconfirmed US media reports, a deal taking shape would include an agreement to extend the government's borrowing authority for two years, meaning no repeat of the current drama before the 2024 presidential election.

;

;Democrats, however, would have to offer concessions on Republican demands for sweeping spending limits on social safety and other domestic programmes.

;

;House Speaker McCarthy told reporters that negotiators had “made progress” but added: “Nothing is agreed to until it's all agreed to.”

;

;A first US debt default in history would likely trigger stock market sell-offs, huge job losses and recession, with major spillover into global economies.

;

;Chinese agency first to downgrade US credit rating as debt-ceiling concerns widen

;

;IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva cited new data that she said showed the “US economy has proven resilient”, but urged a “speedy resolution” to the debt issue.

;

;“We think of the US Treasury market as an anchor for the global financial system, and this anchor needs to hold,” she said.

;

;With the country getting a three day Memorial Day holiday weekend, members of Congress are leaving Washington on their own 10-day recess. Even President Joe Biden – to the consternation of some in his own party – is heading to his Camp David retreat and his private home in Delaware.

;

;Yet Wally Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, told CNN that both Biden and McCarthy were focused on avoiding catastrophe.

;

;“The president decided, the speaker has said it, and we have to get something done before June,” Adeyemo said. “The president is committed to making sure that we have good faith negotiations with the Republicans to reach a deal because the alternative is catastrophic for all Americans.”

;

;On Thursday, Biden had also tried to reassure the country, saying: “There will be no default.”

;

;The debt ceiling raise is an annual accounting manoeuvre that usually passes with relatively little notice. It simply allows the government to keep borrowing money to pay for bills already incurred through the budget.

;

;This year, the increasingly hard-right Republican Party has decided to turn the debt ceiling into leverage to force Biden to roll back favourite Democratic spending priorities.

;

;Republicans call this taking responsibility for the US$31 trillion national debt. The White House accuses the opposition party, which controls the House of Representatives, of taking the economy hostage.

;

;Democratic minority leader Hakeem Jeffries slammed the Republicans from the House floor on Thursday, accusing them of risking “a dangerous default in a crisis that they've created”.

;

;McCarthy Says Republicans and White House 'have time' to reach debt deal

;

;Economists have spent months raising the prospect of economic catastrophe should the government default, and top military brass added their own dire prognosis Thursday, warning that the crisis would have a “significant negative impact” on troops.

;

;“Readiness clearly would be impacted,” Mark Milley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told reporters.

;

;McCarthy has pointed to a recent CNN poll showing 60 per cent support for a debt ceiling hike if accompanied by cuts, although 51 per cent of respondents in a new Monmouth University survey said they wanted the two issues to be separated.

;

;Although lawmakers are on recess, McCarthy has said they will get 24 hours' notice if they are required to return for a vote.

;Citing historical connections, Arthayudh singled out the potential for cooperation with China's Greater Bay Area, a key growth engine in southern China and base of new energy and digital development.

;

;The economic development zone, comprising Hong Kong, Macau and nine mainland cities including Shenzhen and Guangzhou, aims to become China's leading growth and innovation centre, and is already home to leading brands such as telecoms giant Huawei, new energy vehicle producer BYD, internet titan Tencent and drone maker DJI.

;

;Asean was China's largest export destination in the first four months of this year, outpacing the United States and the European Union.

;

;How Thailand is attracting more Chinese tourists than Japan or Australia

;

;Chinese manufacturers are building many factories in Southeast Asia, which has a population of 660 million, and many Chinese technology firms have expanded their market presence in the region.

;

;Thailand, with the second-largest economy in Asean, has traditionally been a favourite destination for Chinese tourists – 5 million are expected to visit the country this year – and a key source of imported rice and tropical fruits.

;

;It is also a key partner of China in developing the pan-Asia high-speed railway network that will extend from Kunming, the capital of China's Yunnan province, to Singapore.

;

;“I think right now the creative [and] new industry is quite prominent,” Arthayudh. “You know, we're talking about clean energy, management of disposable waste. And there's a lot of Chinese companies making all these waste products into building materials, bricks and walls, and towers.”

;

;A report by the International Energy Agency last year said the transition to sustainable energy in Asean member states could provide “greater business opportunities” in the emerging clean energy economy.

;

;Guangdong Governor Wang Weizhong would visit Thailand before the end of next month, the ambassador said, and he hoped both sides could use the opportunity to agree to more cooperation and exchanges.

;

;China to eat first local durians in June. Is Malaysian, Thai dominance at risk?

;

;An annual dialogue mechanism between Guangdong, China's top exporting province, and Thailand has been in place for two decades, with an annual meeting elevated to the ministerial level in the past two years.

;

;Arthayudh said Thais still mainly relied on cash and credit cards for making payments and pencils or water colours for designing, which made it “a more traditional country” that had “a lot to learn from China in terms of fully utilising the digital concept”.

;

;“I think countries in Southeast Asia are a little bit more traditional – [if] you go to Indonesia, Laos, Cambodia, they still don't know the digital way of life,” he said, hinting at great potential for development. “[If] you go to Myanmar, they're still using half-a-century-old techniques … so I think the way forward is digital.”

;

;In a meeting with Assistant Foreign Minister Nong Rong in March, Arthayudh said the comprehensive resumption of exchanges between the two countries at all levels would “deepen coordination and cooperation in multilateral fields including regional cooperation”.

;

;A World Bank report published on May 16 said innovation in Thailand was hampered by a shortage of technical workers, weak scientific production and limited access to finance that constrained the growth of small and medium-sized companies.

;

;“When we look at our relationship with China, it's more than digital or creative industries,” Arthayudh said. “Agriculture is an important area of cooperation between Thailand and China.

;

;“But of course Guangdong is the province that is focusing on creative industries … it is the best source for pushing forward the creative agenda.”

;The International Monetary Fund's managing director slammed the US government on Friday for sending the world into a state of “anxiety” because of the debt ceiling stand-off between President Joe Biden and the country's Republican Party.

;

;Calling the US economy “the ship on which we all travel”, Kristalina Georgieva said she was constantly fielding questions in the international arena about the consequences of a possible US default.

;

;“The US Treasury market is the anchor of stability for the global financial system,” she said. “You pull the anchor and the world economy – the ship on which we all travel – is in choppy, and, even worse, uncharted waters.”

;

;A default would “inevitably” lead to a contraction for the US and world economies, Georgieva added, inflicting “shock upon shock upon shock” on economies that have only recently begun to recover from the coronavirus pandemic and made vulnerable to Russia's war against Ukraine.

;

;Talks on the debt limit impasse between the White House and Republican House Speaker Kevin McCarthy have dragged on for the past week, with both sides signalling progress but not yet reaching an agreement ahead of the so-called “X-date” when the US Treasury would run out of funds to pay its obligations in full.

;

;“It is frustrating for everyone to have a solvable problem that is in the hands of policymakers continuing to linger into the 12th hour,” said Georgieva.

;

;“We all have read the fairy tale about Cinderella having to leave the ball exactly at midnight and we're at this point,” she said.

;

;“Before our carriage turns into a pumpkin, could we please get this solved? It's not just a loss of a shoe that we are faced with.”

;

;IMF says Asia-Pacific to lead global growth in 2023 on back of China rebound

;

;Georgieva downplayed the disruption that the stand-off in Washington was having on global capital markets, characterising it as “a little bit of price impact in some niche markets and … not [amounting to] any significance”.

;

;However, “right now the most significant impact is anxiety around the world over something that should not be a problem to begin with”, she said.

;

;The IMF director implored Washington policymakers to change the system by which borrowing limitations are set to avoid the brinkmanship threatening to undermine global markets.

;

;Instead of setting a debt ceiling independently from annual negotiations that lead to an approved White House budget, Congress could make the borrowing limit automatically match the amount of appropriations it approves in its annual spending bill, she said.
